title: How bad is it to live in Belgium? - Quora

response.answer_text: Terrible, really terrible. 20 years ago we used to peacefully live our quiet life. In the summer we would have our yearly vacation to the North Sea. Enjoying the cold sea breeze when we would walk hand in hand along the undulating sea with the girl we loved, watching seagulls flying a murmuration over the sea at sunset. Feeding the hungry, with some of our delicious regional dishes: grey shrimps stuffed tomatoes, rabbit with prunes, or mussels with Fries. finishing with a Dame blanche or coupe brésilienne with lots of whipped cream. Quenching the thirsty with a good Trappist beer watching people stroll by our terrace at the sea-dike, commenting on their bad sense of fashing or how their stubborn Chihuahua is giving a new meaning to a canine carnage. Things were so simple and uncomplicated. Belgium basically had a monopoly on Trappist beers. We only had to cover up with the proverbial mantle of love that La Trappe was brewed a few km outside the Belgium border. With La Trappe, our Northern neighbors had at a good beer brand so we shrugged it off and gracefully accepted La Trappe as technically from the Netherlands (It is not exactly a big accomplishment to be better as Heineken so the Dutch should not get too excited.) But look what happened now. Currently, you have Trappist beer from Austria, Italy, and the United States.The United States of all places!? I tasted Spencer Trappist.Because of BNBR rules on Quora, I wouldn’t go that far to call it an abomination, but I’m not so sure it will make America great again either. Our traditional food is not traditional anymore we now have to follow the latest Culinary food hypes. Seaweed tacos anyone!? Turmeric, quinoa and chia seeds. We can’t drink plain water or beer. No, we have to have lemon flavored water or even coconut water or fermented liquids like kombucha. The harder to pronounce the better it seems The seagull —who used to be a welcome guest at our coast— is getting more and more aggressive and is now a real plague. Admiring beautiful girls in polka dots bikinis at the beach is not politically correct behavior anymore either, you need to ignore them and focus on your book. To conclude it is not as it used to be in Belgium, but if I may quote my late grandmother: ‘If you are complaining about these little flaws, you do not have any real problems.’ I guess that summarizes the situation in Belgium rather accurately.

I’m Belgian, and no I don't like Belgium: I know there is worse out there, way worse but Belgium is no longer safe. It's the feeding ground for terrorism and other criminal activities. Ever since we've opened our borders with the euro and not adapted our social security system, we have been overrun by bottom feeders and opportunists. We pay social benefits to people whom own property in other countries. It has been discovered that about 40 percent of people getting benefits have one or more villa or house in another country. As Belgians we pay for that ( hence the high taxes) It doesn't matter to our government that people choosing to live here commit crimes, they are hardly ever expelled or even have their social benefits retracted. When official instances are made aware of the criminal income some of their beneficiaries have, they decline to withdraw the payments because: “ they receive funding according to the amount of people requesting benefits” Politicians are utterly uncaring about real problems and remain content as long as they fill their pockets. Their main concerns are banalities like banning words such as allochtoon and making it into multicultureel. Companies based in Belgium, doing their damnedest to stay above board and legal, are harpooned by companies from other countries ( Poland, Roumanie, Bulgaria,…) who go under the possible selling price of Belgian companies, nothing is done about it. In 2017 110000 Belgian based companies didn't file their tax returns … because they are companies used as shell companies for fraude or other criminal activities. Nothing is done about it. People with social benefits can own a house (in Belgium!!!!), go on holiday 7 times a year to countries, I as a working member will never be able to afford, have 590.000 euro transferring through their bank accounts in 5 years time and no one does a thing about it… logic anyone? Preying on a social security system, while spending money like Kim kardashian? Ridiculous much? They force you to buy new cars that have a decent euro emission, yet they let the prices of suitable cars skyrocket, very motivational especially when as added bonus your non conformed car IS BANNED from big cities and you must pay a fine if you do enter. So tough luck if you can’t afford buying a car that will cost you at least 15000 EUR. You want to work in a big city? Comply to the emission norms mofo!. We are one of the most expensive gas counties in the world btw. But hey we have public transportation right? Uhuh if only they weren’t on strike every two seconds, or about as reliable as a voodoo witch doctor in a horror movie! Also did you know bread around here costs 2.20 euro? Do we cultivate golden grain or what? They tease you with premiums and advantages for solar panels, than they force you to pay taxes on them because they miscalculated. only to go on to the next “let’s scam the population plan”… windmills ( trust me, those will be paying taxes soon too) They rid their overload of electricity by paying other countries to take it off our hands in the summer, too many solar panels you see… THAN they need to buy electricity in the winter because our so called nuclear reactors are failing ? Does anyone else see the irony of this?? So you pay extra in summer to get rid of your electricity that they enticed you to produce and than they make you pay AGAIN because during winter they don’t have enough and need to buy elsewhere. Only in Belgium… No one else would swallow this crap… coup d’état would happen in any other country on the mere principle of the thing… Unemployment is going everywhere because other countries around us are cheaper, way cheaper. Why pay someone double the salary if you can start a satellite company in Poland and pay the workers less tax heavy minimum polish wages? Or hell pay him under the table, no taxes necessary… We have 48 ministers ( and 10 Secretaries of State) where countries thrice our size have 8, and naturally we pay them a tax free salary of a whopping amount between 6000 and 17000 euro per month. Our prime minister earns more than the fucking president of the United States! Fun fact: our Constitution says every Belgian is equal before the law: yeah depending on which province, community or part of Belgian you live in. No one pays the same taxes, or gets the same advantages … and of course wether or not you’re and immigrant or a citizen. Working paying citizens get persecuted to the extend of the law, whilst bottom feeders receive a notice to leave the country. A letter people, they receive A.LETTER. ( *facedesks*).… and of course all those nice people leave immediately. *cough* Ps did you know our country once decided to pay 580 euro PeR DAy because certain fugitive families didn’t have living quarters?? Meanwhile they REFUSED to go to the barracks that were set up for them for “ lack of privacy” and we actually swallow that shit!!! You take refuge in our country, we let you stay, provide food and shelter and than you have the AUDACITY to DEMAND better and more? Yep here it’s possible… I pay 53 percent taxes on my salary. I calculated this, I don’t know the percentages published but this is the amount of my wage that I don’t get in hand. Single parents barely have any advantages. When a modal tax paying citizen commits a crime he'll be paying for his mistake the rest of his life. When career criminals commit crimes they keep living the life, merely because they don't have any official income, yet they earn more than we do, they just don't put it in bank accounts. They drive Audi, Mercedes or BMW. Wear Calvin Klein and Boss and not the fake stuff and manage to get paid for schticking it to the citizen. You can open bank accounts here in any name as long as you have a copy of an ID. ANY.ID… You can take out loans without ever having to see anyone in person. Seriously … Elderly People are targeted a lot here because, due to their ailments and need for dependency they confide their official documents to people whom have no qualms about abusing the weaker people in our society. Also you can deviate people‘s mail with one single email and no one is the wiser… you d think the government would demand banks and BE postal office to maintain stricter policy… but nooooo. Copkillers get liberated after ten years because they were sentenced to 30 years and did 1/3 of their time. one.third.!!! It has become a free loaders emperium. And the good working citizens are paying. Crime rates have shot up drastically since 2000. And we are being left behind. We are literally mopping the floor with all the taps open… In some parts of our country they don't even use the Dutch, German or French language anymore … we can't even read what's in those stores, or what service they’re providing. Fun fact: They ( our government) are considering making officials speak ARAB in Brussels. I mean WTF? I’m all for being client oriented but fuck, some of the effort has to come from the other side!! Drugs, terrorism, fraude are thé most popular crimes here. We do not have a reference based home rental system, so home owners renting out their property have realistic chance of finding drug labs or cannabis plantations in them. Your ( snail) mail can easily be intercepted, since the BE postal service does absolutely nothing to secure it ( overflow bags are put into building entrances for anyone to access). This allows people to modify the account numbers on invoices or money transfer orders and send them on like nothing has happened. Belgium seems nice, Belgium seems rich but we're are going down the drain fast and no one is doing a damn thing about it. We are the most apathetic people to exist.. the worst we ever do is…. “go on strike”… ( omg no not a strike! That’s so useful… im so embarrassed with our talent for doing nothing useful) which is the equivalent of shooting in your own foot since this only impacts the modal working citizen…. Also I wanted to add that we don't really have a democratic system anymore. Why? Because very simply our votes do not count. Parties, have long upfront, decided what they need to do or have for a majority vote. If their party doesn't win they make the necessary coalitions to remain in power … it's fake and frustrating, especially when you don't have a choice wether or not you vote, since it's mandatory. Our system permits anyone to have a party in politics so there are as many parties as there are ministers … we suck. Set all that aside and you’ll find yourself in a densely populated area with a “me and mine first” attitude that isn’t exactly inviting nor pleasant. Though like for any other thing said… not everyone here is like that. Do we have social security and free health care? Absolutely! Is this a luxury? yessir mam! But the whole friggin world knows we do and comes here to take advantage of it. Do we have cheap but quality education! Yes we do!! We also have understaffed badly maintained schools with frayed and exhausted teachers who are not considered for the “heavy labour”professions due to “ lots of days off” The fact that these teachers stand in front of classrooms with 30 or more kids, ALONE, and that they often need to work until 11 in the evening.. is of no issue whatsoever.( Fuck most of us are parents and we get tired handling two kids, for three hours after work… imagine 9 hrs a day…) and that’s me not mentioning the non Flemish or French or English speaking kids tossed into a 5 th grade without any former language training or discussing kids with parents WHO Do Not Speak ANY of our languages. Do we have decent salaries? Ministers and CEO with triple cumul do… us average people we get by… living in Belgium according to a normal standard will cost you at least 1600 euro per month and that’s really a bare minimum. If your kid has a past time, grows and devours clothes and food, you own a car and pay rent, your average living cost will soon be 2 k per month… and I can guarantee you that the average single parent does not have 2 k per month in wages.

I see you already got the perspective of the not rich born . I fall in that same bloc but i’m not really well educated , rather self educated … I could pay to go to school but since my father & his sort of wife both teached in state schools , i went on state money . No Uni for me cause i wanted to be a soldier , so i went to school there at 16 & they payed good money to wear kaki’s & to feed you to the brim with great food !Healthcare for military personnel is even cheaper if you let yourself be treated by military docters , i never paid anything , never received a bill … Even your family is included (wife & kids have that choice )I lived on Base for 3 yrs in my own private studio-appartment for the monthly price of 1 visit to the barber … My meals were priced between 99 cents & 2 euro’s . No car needed for groceries & the military gets you 30% off on train . To this day , 26 yrs after enlisting i’ve never paid for a bus ride neither .I do not own my own house but live in social housing , for wich i pay less than the upcoming Playstation Classic . But since i had to wait for years on end to get in one , the governement pays the rent partly back for the same amount of time i had to wait (minus 5 yrs ) .These days i’m an handicapped . I’ve been home for 2 yrs , i’d rather work but they said “enough is enough” ! Perhaps after brain surgery i will be able to try working again . Since i’m in this position , the rent will be decreased again , no more car taxes . The healtcare association i’m in has asked me to come in so they can help to get more grants & benefits . I pay no more than 1 Euro for a docters visit or meds .Although i hear many people in Belgium complain about high taxes - wich is true - i do not , most of my life i got money back … no complaints here …So between Nicolas his statement on Belgium & mine we’re pretty much happy & covered , i would think !Belgium has real freedom , great food , best beer & great , social people … And although grass can be greener elsewhere - not saying it is - this is pretty much the greatest small country to live !

Hi, as king of Belgium, I feel obligated to answer your question. Belgium is an amazing country, which has a lot of special properties not found in any other country, not even in Europe. Its on the top list of developed countries, governed by democracy, a rather high level of multicultural tolerance, social solidarity and hospitality. Always on the front of innovation, founder of Europe, not taking bullying from big powers as US or Russia, or even Oil providing Middle East countries. Protecting human rights, big supporter of U.N. This all besides a very modest pride about it. But you are not asking what the good sides are. Your question stipulates how “bad” it is to live in Belgium. Well, lets focus on that : Living in Belgium first comes with bad weather. The climate is good for agriculture, but even summers can be as wet as winter, which can be cold, windy and dirty as just not enough freezing to keep the snow solid and clean. Although last summer was exceptional warm with the longes heatwave since long time, but thats contributed to global warming (?).Taxes are extremely high. Look up the list, Belgium is either number one or two with the highest income tax possible in the world. Its only since a few years that the highest tax scale was reduced from 60% to 50% (yes, there was a time you paid 60% of your income to taxes). And do not forget, these taxes are calculated on your income after subtraction of an already very high social security amount. So now, for 50.000euro a year, you get to keep only 29.448euro.So, as you pay much for social security, the system is very good. If you have nothing: 0euro, no house, no job, no nothing… you will still not have to sleep in the streets. But, immigrants and parasites also now this, so there is a lot of abuse. You will have to live with the fact that this foreigner with a villa or two in Morocco, gets a monthly minimum wage without working. He gets a house from social security which he pays rent 3 times less than you. He gets almost free access to public transport and medical services, which you pay for. So its only bad to live in Belgium if you have a job and work for your money.Being sick, or pretending to be, is also not bad in Belgium. The same benefits apply as described above. Being healthy on the other hand, will make you carry the burden, and you will have to be able to watch your “sick” neighbour, who gets his monthly allowance from medical social insurance, go on holiday for mountain hiking three times a year.Belgium has three official languages. Dutch, French and German. Almost nobody speaks German so forget about that. More than half the country speaks Dutch, but when they meet another language person, they will adapt. Any foreigner that comes to Belgium, just speaks his own language, and Belgians adapt, so expect to be put in that position.Planning for houses and roads is a mess. People can build any kind of style house almost anywhere. Hence it looks like chaos. Roads are either brand new or age old, with bad maintenance. It depends on which government, county, or community needs to take care of it.Every road, how bad it may be, has lights for visibility. They were once put there partly because our nuclear power plants produced to much electricity at night which had to be spend somehow. Now, these lights, even on highways are mostly turned of, depending on the exces of electricity that is available. Now that these nuclear power plants are getting broken of old age, the next step is, to switch of entire communities to save electricity. The list in which order they will be switched of is already distributed. Expected timeframe : this november-december.If you’r english language native, and used to a “querty” keyboard, get ready for a change : Belgium uses the “azerty” keyboard layout, as in France. Main difference is that numbers are accessed through the shift-key and the general layout is different.I almost forgot, but one thing you will not understand when you live in Belgium, because its so bad, is the political system. There are 3 political regions, each with their own parlement and ministers and president. Then there is also the federal government with prime minister and parlement and chamber of representatives. And than the worse : Belgium is also a kingdom so that this guy gets the final vote on any law that has to be passed. So don’t expect to know whats happening soon.And I probably forgot a number of things because I’m so used to leaving here. So ask me a specific question and I’ll answer :-)

Edit and warning: I live in the southern part of Belgium, and this country is divided in two. The north and the south do not even share the same language. My experience is with the southern part. — I’m 30 and I was born in Belgium. I lived in Greece for 4 months (Erasmus program, in Thessaloniki). I visited Israel twice, and the northern part of Italy and the Netherlands briefly. About taxes : taxes are high, and I hate it, but a great part of it is actually redistributed in services. The health system is exceptionally good, while public transportation is exceptionally bad (you just can’t rely on it to be at work on time, even when there is no strike). I have a friend that left for Singapore saying “it’s true that the health system is good, but still, is it worth that much in taxes?”. The answer is, probably not. To give you an idea : with benefits from the system, my father, having no diploma, was able to raise 3 kids on a single salary and send all three of them to University. I was even allowed by the system to flunk and flunk again until I reached 26. Health : as I said, the health system is exceptionally good. You have good doctors and hospitals everywhere, and everybody can afford it. Education : the quality is probably average in a developed country, but it’s very affordable. The tuition for University is around 900€ a year, which makes it basically free. Housing : it’s very expensive. And it’s very difficult to own a house as a young worker, as the government takes 13 percent of the value of the house when you acquire it. A decent house is 200k. Which means the government is going to take 26k just to show you it can. As a relatively young worker that wants to buy a house, I find that outrageous. Prejudice : Belgium is divided in two parts. The northern part is very different from the southern part. I’m a white christian, so I cannot say I encountered many prejudices based on my skin color or my religion. But I currently learn Hebrew, and I meet Jewish people at the language school. Life is clearly not fun for them in today’s Belgium. They have to hide the fact they are Jewish. Also, we aren’t allowed to stay in front of the school, and should disperse instead. The teacher was happy to have a policeman among its students. That’s how tense the situation is for them. What makes me want to leave Belgium is the feeling of lack of opportunities, which seems to be caused by such high taxes, and the perceived lack of ambition of most people (a lot of that feeling comes from the fact people vote often for extreme leftist parties like the PTB). At the same time, I know the system gave me a lot, through health and education. So, it’s all relative. Belgium is probably in the top 20 countries where life is the most comfortable and if people complain constantly, this is because life here is extremely easy. All in all, I would still leave for a country like Singapore if given the opportunity.

*native story, ninja cutting onions spoiler alert* I have lived in Belgium for 22 years and recently moved to the Netherlands. Belgium is great until you randomly move somewhere else and understand it’s better. There are good things in Belgium, especially in Flanders, the area where I am from just looks like a massive crowd of people on Redbull, unemployment money and complaining all day long. Healthcare isn’t bad, crime isn’t too bad to be visible to citizens (except some famous crime infested cities, of course). Your salary and the cost of life are pretty okay if you know how to handle money. Taxes are high as hell, which would be okay if we actually saw where the money is going. I quickly realized this environment is not what will help me be happy. My uncle left Belgium around the same age as me and told me there is nothing good for me there. I moved to Utrecht, in the Netherlands earlier this year. The bus drivers are rarely on strike, the police has time to focus on accidents and bigger crimes because the city has “Handhaving”, people who take care of minor offences (badly parked cars, bikes, neighbour issues, etc.) People spontaneously greet you on the street or at least acknowledge you, they generally take care of their health, enjoy working and also having fun. I am not sure if it is the mentality, the history of the country or simply a more “northern” way to live, but the environment is much better. I am much happier. I am surrounded by people who are interested in what I do, people who support my activities outside of work, people who want to succeed and see others succeed. The Netherlands is a country focused on progress. All products that are lifestyle/health or technology related seem to come from the Netherlands and hit the rest of Europe afterwards. I have reached the point where I am ready to give up my Belgian nationality to get the Dutch one, without hesitation, which I will do in five years if all goes according to plan. I am ashamed and I feel sick when going back to Belgium. I see all the people that cannot reach the next step in their life because of the way they think. I believe there are good and bad people everywhere. If you see much bigger than the bigger picture, move where people have the same vision. Belgium is a broken corrupted country, a failed Beta lagging version of the Netherlands.

For a slighty less sarcastic and fantastic answer than Nicolas’, read on :-) Belgium has fantastic healthcare paid mostly by the stateBelgium has a great social security system that will take care of you when you are ill, unemployed or otherwise unfit to workBelgium has a great education system where children are required to go to school starting age 6 until 18 with (almost) free education and well subsidized higher education of high qualityThere are very strict rules on gun ownershipTransportation is multimodal allowing you to get from A to B in several waysYes we have a very high tax rate, but considering what you get back, it’s rather public insurance than a nuisance in my opinionFreedom of speech is encouragedEqual rights are mostly applied, with only occasional minorities being suppressed or assaultedUnemployment is at the lower sideWe are especially good at waste management, sorting electrical, batteries, plastics, paper, glass, metal, wood, …So in general, we are not the best country to live in, in any aspect, but with this unique combination of safety, unemployment numbers, social security, healthcare and educational opportunities, we rock the top of the world, I’m sure. But there is always room for improvement.

I am a Belgian, 61 years old and it is not so bad living here, except for a couple of things that are very annoying, due to the dense population:- there are traffic jams everywhere since cities are so close to each other, let’s say you have a city about every 50 km from each other and many people just seem to work in another city so having to ride from one to another.- the light pollution is so bad, there is not a single place where you can see the Milky Way, certainly not in the north (flemish) region.- talking about regions: a small country (11 million people), but 6 governments and 6 parliaments, because of the historical division of the flemish part, the french part and the Brussels region. And not to forget: a German part in the east, acquired after WW I, Belgium got a piece of Germany as a compensation. (that’s why - before the Euro was introduced - there were 3 languages printed on Belgian banknotes!). There is of course a federal government as well. This means serious problems never get fully solved.- Luckily, I cannot complain about the healthcare system.

Its hard for me to compare as I have never lived anywhere else but I would think: ‘Not very bad at all’. Sure our political system is a complete shambles, taxation is quite high and we are on the verge of a bit of an energy crisis. It is not all peachy keen. But on the other hand education and health care are fairly affordable and of a good quality. The tap water is safe to drink. The weather is a bit rainy at times but never extreme (no monsoons, serious draughts or tornados). The food is good and the beer is great. Perfect? No. Bad? Hell no.

If you are a Belgian citizen, it is probably fine. If you are an expat: the tax is very very very high, compared to neighbor countries like the Netherlands or France. On the other hand, you probably cannot access the great services the government offers to their citizens, such as free education - you probably finish your education before moving to Belgium to work. In other words, you work, pay tax but did not get (all of them) back. Furthermore, as an expat who works in Belgium, you probably spend your most beautiful time (25 - 50 probably) in the country. Unfortunately, this is the period of your life that you do not need the healthcare service most.

If you hold a proper job, it actually is quite OK, a lot less regulated than in The Netherlands where I now live. People by and large have more money to spend, from what I’ve seen from my friends, although much more formal than in The Netherlands. On the other hand, my son’s friend, a pilot for Ryan Air, flying out of Charleroi airport located in poor(er) Wallonia where many were jobless, chose not to live there due to crime issues…. Not an issue AFAIK in prosperous Flanders. Not sure about the Muslim migrant issues, seen in Antwerp and Brussels, where many live concentrated in ghettos, but AFAIK not as bad as the French banlieus.

We’re a mixture of northern reserve and southern sloppiness (please excuse the cliché). Our urban and suburban planning is almost non-existent and at the same time our rules are maddeningly frustrating, which makes any sight-seeing trip a journey for unexpected and wonderful treasures among otherwise butt-ugly architecture. The business climate is equally paradoxal, it seems like everything goes and rules are laxly enforced, but at the same time entrepreneurs complain (rightly so) about harsh, complex and difficult regulations. But our cooking is the best of French cuisine served in German quantities. And we love quality and variety, so you will find plenty of other cuisines from all over the world in excellent and nice restaurants at a fairly affordable price point. Also quality of living is important to us. Houses are still fairly cheap to buy and keep. It’s a large part of what we do: buy a house, maintain the house, enjoy the house for as long as you can and then pass it on to your children.

US is often used as the reference when it comes to welfare or quality of life. Lets us take the “gun” way to illustrate how “bad” Belgium is compared to US. Crimes/100.000 habitants: 4,62 in US and 0,14 in Belgium. Suicides/100.000 habitants: 7,10 in US and 1.03 in Belgium. Source: Wikipedia. Salary spread between top manager and lower level worker. US: 360 times; Europe: 74 times.

I think it is probably one of the worlds most normal and most mainstream countries with the smallest amount of problems (often inflated by foreign media for reasons beyond my comprehension) and the highest grade of democracy. We complain, as does everyone on this planet, but we hardly ever move away because if you consider the whole package, no country in the world can beat us.
